# **Practical application** {#chap:practical-app}
\minitoc  <!--this will include a mini table of contents-->

\chaptermark{Practical application}

In this final chapter we are going to describe the practical application of the models described in section \@ref(chap:models) on an actuarial dataset. After describing the problem and how the models have been implemented, we will assess their performance and comment the results.


## Data description

The dataset used is an actuarial dataset from an Italian MTPL portfolio. In total in the dataset there are 283829 rows for a total of 134805 years-at-risk. In the dataset, every row is a couple (policy, accounting year), so, if a policy spans in two years, we will see two rows corresponding to that policy. On average, every row has exposure 0.475 years-at-risk. This number is slightly lower than 0.5 because some of the policies get suspended and last more than two years.

The data comes from the policies of a province in the period 2014-2019. The fact that the provinces comes from one specific province reduces a lot the size of the dataset. As the models has been run locally on a single computer, this significantly reduces the time spent to run the models. From a modeling point of view, the reduction to only one province reduces the importance of the geography in the models. Between the different regions of Italy there are a lot of difference from a socio-economical point of view that are reflected to the claims experience. In this thesis the problem of using geographical data as explanatory variables has not been faced

The dataset has been split in a training set with 80% of the observations and a test set with the remaining 20% of the observations. The training set will be used to fit the models, while the test set will be used to assess them by comparing the predictions of the models with the observed data. The splitting has been made on the base of the policyholder id. That means that contracts from the same policyholder end in the same set. This splitting prevents data leakage from the test set to the training set.

The response variable for the models is the number of claims caused by the policyholder in that policy and accounting year.
